contextId.information: Here "prostitution" represents the people being unfaithful to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: great prostitution

contextId.information: This expression refers to kingdom of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the house of Israel

contextId.information: Here "mother" refers to the nation of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your mother

contextId.information: A wife who is adulterous leaves her husband to sleep with another man. This is how Israel was acting toward Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and her acts of adultery

contextId.information: Here "thirst" refers to the need to worship and rely on Yahweh, not idols, or Israel will not be able to survive as a nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and I will make her die from thirst

contextId.information: This refers to payment that Israel received from the false gods or Baals. This direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "that these were the wages that her lovers had given to her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
contextId.quote: These are the wages that my lovers gave me

contextId.information: Yahweh will be like the husband, and Israel will be like Yahweh's wife. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will promise to be your husband forever

contextId.information: When God makes his people safe and prosperous in their land again, they are spoken of if they were agricultural crops. AT: "I will take care of the Israelite people as a farmer plants his crops and takes care of them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will plant her for myself in the land

contextId.information: Here "stumble" means to disobey God or even to stop trusting him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You priests will stumble

contextId.information: Here "mother" refers to the nation of Israel. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:hos:02:02|2:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will destroy your mother

contextId.information: Yahweh will destroy the nation of Israel because they do not understand or obey God's commandments. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So this people who does not understand will be thrown down

contextId.information: Here "wind" represents God's judgment and anger against the nation of Israel. Yahweh will allow the enemy army to defeat the people of Israel and take them as captives. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The wind will wrap her up in its wings

contextId.information: As a lion tears apart the animal it is eating, so Yahweh will tear his people away from their homes and country. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will tear

contextId.information: Making Israel obedient to God again and receivers of his blessing is spoken of as if it were healing. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I want to heal Israel

contextId.information: The people's evil deeds are probably spoken of here as if they were other people ready to accuse them of their crimes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: their deeds surround them

contextId.information: The people committed spiritual adultery by worshiping idols and being unfaithful to Yahweh. They were probably also being unfaithful to their husbands or wives by sleeping with other people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They are all adulterers

contextId.information: However, this "old age" is clearly a way of saying that the northern kingdom is getting weaker and weaker, because the nation does not know it is "old." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but he does not know it

contextId.information: This is a way to catch birds. Yahweh continues to compare the people of Israel to doves. When they go to Egypt or Assyria for help, Yahweh will punish them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will spread my net over them

contextId.information: Here no longer worshiping God is spoken of as turning away from him. AT: "and they no longer worship me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and they turn away from me

contextId.information: This may be a military metaphor, in which God training the Israelites to love him and obey him is spoken of as if he had been training their men for war. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Though I trained them and strengthened their arms

contextId.information: "swallowed" means to be defeated and taken into exile. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The enemies of Israel have taken the Israelites away to other lands" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Israel is swallowed up

contextId.information: Ephraim's alliances with other nations are spoken of as if they had paid them to become prostitutes for Ephraim. AT: "The people of Israel have tried to pay other nations to protect them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Ephraim has hired lovers for herself

contextId.information: This is food that the Israelites would normally refuse to eat because it would make them unacceptable to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: unclean food

contextId.information: A "watchman" watches outside his city to see if danger is coming. The prophet warning the people when they are sinning and are in danger of having his God punish them is spoken of as if he were a watchman for the city. AT: "The prophet is like a watchman for God over Ephraim" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The prophet is the watchman for my God over Ephraim

contextId.information: Israel is spoken of as a vine that was very fruitful. For a while the people prospered and were strong. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Israel is a luxuriant vine that produces his fruit

contextId.information: This passage probably means that the people of the present time continue to act in the same ways that their ancestors did at Gibeah. AT: "and you think just as they did" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: there you have remained

contextId.information: The result of deception are spoken of as if they were a food that could be eaten. AT: "You now suffer the consequences of having deceived each other" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You have eaten the fruit of deception

contextId.information: Yahweh is speaking about the people of Israel as if they were a young man. Yahweh is referring to when he first started his relationship with the nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: When Israel was a young man

contextId.information: Yahweh refers to Israel as a small child whom he taught to walk. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: it was I who taught Ephraim to walk

contextId.information: Yahweh stating that the people of Judah have sinned against him and broken his covenant is spoken of as if Yahweh were accusing them in court. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:hos:04:01|4:1]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh also has a lawsuit against Judah

contextId.information: The idea of making someone suffer the results of his own actions is spoken of as if those actions were objects that were thrown back at him. AT: "will make him suffer from his own disgraceful actions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will turn back on him his disgrace

contextId.information: When the people of Ephraim began worshiping Baal, they grew weak, and their enemies defeated them. Here "died" refers to the nation growing weak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: but he became guilty because of Baal worship, and he died

contextId.information: The northern kingdom's iniquity and guilt are spoken of as if they were objects that could be kept for a purpose. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: has been stored up

contextId.information: Not to think about having compassion is spoken of as if compassion were hidden so that it cannot be seen. AT: "I have no compassion for them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Compassion is hidden from my eyes

contextId.information: This expression seems to stand for the nations around the northern kingdom, especially Judah, the southern kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his brothers

contextId.information: Stopping the people from turning away from God is spoken of as if he were healing them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will heal their turning away

contextId.information: The people of Israel will once again live protected by God. Israel is spoken of as living in his shade. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The people who live in his shade will return

contextId.information: Disobeying Yahweh is spoken of as if it were stumbling while walking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]
contextId.quote: stumble
